channel.title: British Columbia news - MSN CA
channel.description: News and information from British Columbia - News - MSN CA

item.title: Trinity Western blasts N.S., Ontario law societies
item.description: At issue is Trinity Western's requirement that its 3,600 students sign a community covenant forbidding intimacy outside heterosexual marriage, which has been criticized as discriminatory against gays and lesbians.

item.title: Man, woman found drunk in car with 3-year-old son
item.description: North Vancouver police were shocked to find a man and woman heavily intoxicated in a car Thursday morning - with the woman's three-year-old son in the backseat.

item.title: Foreign worker program abuse won't be tolerated, Jason Kenney warns
item.description: The government's decision to impose moratorium on the fast-food industry's access to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program will send employers "a very clear message" that abuse will not be tolerated, says Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: B.C. teachers negotiations heading for stalemate
item.description: The B.C. government's chief negotiator says bargaining with the provincial Teacher's Federation is reaching a stalement, which may mean more job action by B.C. teachers.

item.title: Murder-suicide of Prince Rupert, B.C, mother, autistic son under review
item.description: B.C.'s Representative for Children and Youth is reviewing the murder-suicide of a mother and her autistic son after an advocate for the rights of people with disabilities called the incident a wakeup call for the province.

item.title: B.C. teachers negotiations heading toward stalemate
item.description: The chief negotiator for the B.C. government says bargaining with the B.C. Teacher's Federation is reaching a statement, and that could mean further job action by B.C.'s 41,000 teachers.

item.title: N.S. law society grants conditional approval for Trinity Western grads
item.description: Nova Scotia's bar society has voted to conditionally approve Trinity Western University's proposed new law school a day after barristers in Ontario ruled not to accredit the faith-based institution.

item.title: Foreign workers fill more than just fast-food jobs, Jason Kenney says
item.description: Canadian employers hire temporary foreign workers to fill more than just jobs in the food sector and shutting down the Temporary Foreign Worker Program would have negative consequences for the Canadian economy, says Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: Foreign workers hired to fill more than just fast-food jobs, Jason Kenney says
item.description: Canadian employers hire temporary foreign workers to fill more than just jobs in the food sector and shutting down the Temporary Foreign Worker Program would have negative consequences for the Canadian economy, says Employment Minister Jason Kenney.

item.title: Murder-suicide of Prince Rupert mother, autistic son raises questions
item.description: A disability advocate is calling the murder-suicide of a B.C. mother and her autistic son a wakeup call for the province.

item.title: Senate reform can't be done by Ottawa alone
item.description: Parliament cannot go it alone when it comes to substantial Senate reform, the Supreme Court of Canada said in a unanimous decision released today. That puts a significant roadblock in the way of nearly all reforms proposed by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, who called the ruling a "decision for the status quo."

item.title: More aboriginal women taking on trades despite challenges
item.description: Kimberley Kessel is a 20-year-old woman of the Squamish and Haida-Gwaii Nations, and one of 48 students at the Squamish Nation Trades Centre. The centre offers free trades training in courses such as shipbuilding and carpentry, and 15-20% of the students are female.

item.title: Prescription drug shortages compromising patient care
item.description: Pharmacists warn a worsening drug shortage is making it increasingly difficult to supply medications for patients and that's compromising their medical care.

item.title: Massachusetts domestic violence program may have lessons for B.C.
item.description: A Masschusetts crisis centre says B.C. could benefit from a state law that allows the incarceration of abusers for up to 90 days in potential domestic violence cases.

item.title: Anti-immigration flyers upset Brampton residents
item.description: Peel Regional Police are investigating allegations of racism over an anti-immigration pamphlet being circulated in Brampton, Ont.

item.title: Hastings Racecourse honours photographer with her own race
item.description: The Hastings Racecourse kicks off its 125th season this Sunday, and as usual, Patti Tubbs will be on the track, snapping photos - this time for a race named in her honour.

item.title: Trinity Western law school rejected by Ontario law society
item.description: The Law Society of Upper Canada has voted 28 to 21against the accreditation of Trinity Western University's proposed new law school in B.C. That means law graduates from the B.C. university would not be able to practise in Ontario.

item.title: Thi Yen Le killed in targeted attack in Stanley Park
item.description: Vancouver police have identified the woman killed in Stanley Park early Thursday morning as 33-year-old Thi Yen Le of Surrey.

item.title: Temporary Foreign Worker Program for fast-food sector suspended by Ottawa
item.description: Employment Minister Jason Kenney has announced an immediate moratorium on the fast-food industry's access to the Temporary Foreign Worker Program.

item.title: Tim Hortons breaks with franchisee, expands foreign worker oversight after wage theft claims
item.description: Tim Hortons has expanded oversight of the use of temporary foreign workers at its franchises and taken over two locations in Fernie, B.C., and Blairmore, Alta., months after several employees told CBC News the owner of the two franchises took advantage of their status as temporary foreign workers to cheat them out of overtime pay.

item.title: Yukon RCMP seek man not seen by family for 5 years
item.description: Gregory Hrenyk, 43, was last seen in Watson Lake in October 2009, hitchhiking south on the Alaska Highway.

item.title: Meet Griffin and Maverick, Vancouver's new police pups
item.description: Vancouver police have released the names picked for two German shepherd puppies by two elementary school classes

item.title: Temporary Foreign Worker Program linked to joblessness: report
item.description: The government's Temporary Foreign Worker Program nudges the unemployment rate higher in some sectors of the economy and parts of the country, think-tank C.D. Howe says in a report.

item.title: Tim Hortons breaks with franchisee after foreign workers claim wage theft
item.description: The head office of Tim Hortons has taken over two franchises in Fernie, B.C., and Blairmore, Alta., months after several temporary foreign workers told CBC News the owner cheated them out of overtime pay.

item.title: Stanley Park death: Woman killed in targeted attack
item.description: A woman who died in Stanley Park early Thursday morning was the victim of a targeted attack, say Vancouver police.

item.title: Ferrari impounded for hitting 181 km/h in Surrey
item.description: A 49-year-old man stopped for driving 181 km/h in his Ferrari, with a child in the car, has been fined $483 for excessive speeding and his vehicle impounded for seven days.

item.title: Stinging Nettles: Greens with a Bite
item.description: Spring is here, which means stinging nettles abound, and the once lowly weed has now been elevated to haute cuisine.

item.title: Arson suspect sought in 3 Mission fires
item.description: Police in Mission, B.C., are looking for an arson suspect after several suspicious fires broke out around 2 a.m. PT Thursday morning.

item.title: Chinese drivers' licences now accepted by B.C. RCMP
item.description: RCMP in B.C. have reached an agreement with ICBC to stop ticketing drivers from China who are temporarily using their drivers' licences while in the province.

item.title: Is fetal tissue from B.C. used to power Oregon homes?
item.description: An Oregon county commission has ordered an incinerator to stop accepting boxed medical waste to generate electricity after learning the waste it has been burning may include tissue from aborted fetuses from British Columbia.

item.title: Good Samaritan gives his shoes to barefoot bus passenger
item.description: An off-duty Coast Mountain bus driver says it was a bus ride he'll never forget, after seeing a stranger give the shoes off his feet to a barefoot passenger in Surrey, B.C.

item.title: B.C. earthquake: 6.6-magnitude quake hits near Port Alice
item.description: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck last night shortly after 8 p.m. PT, with the epicentre located 40 kilometres southwest of Port Alice, according to the Pacific Tsunami Information Centre.

item.title: B.C. earthquake: 6.6 magnitude quake hits near Port Alice, B.C.
item.description: A 6.6 magnitude earthquake struck Wednesday night shortly aftter 8 p.m. PT. The epicentre was located 40 kilometres southwest of Port Alice at a depth of 22 kilometres, according to the Pacific Tsunami Information Centre.

item.title: B.C. earthquake: 6.7 magnitude quake hits near Port Alice, B.C.
item.description: A 6.7 magnitude earthquake has struck 40 kilometres northwest of Port Alice at a depth of 22 kilometres, the Pacific Tsunami Information Centre reports.

item.title: Good Samaritan gives shoes off his feet to bus passenger
item.description: An off duty Coast Mountain bus driver says it was a bus ride he'll never forget after he saw a stranger give the shoes off his feet to a passenger who had none last Saturday.

item.title: Drivers' privacy concerns grow over B.C. car dealer scanner
item.description: The head of the New Car Dealers Association of B.C. says he hasn't seen any members uploading drivers' licences onto marketing software, a day after a CBC undercover investigation found B.C. car dealers may be violating customers' privacy rights.

item.title: Abbotsford police shoot mentally ill man with rubber bullets
item.description: Activists in Abbotsford, B.C., are outraged by what they say was unnecessary force that police used in the takedown of a mentally ill homeless man in that city last week. But police say the use of non-lethal force was approppriate.

item.title: Chloe the stolen French bulldog reunited with owner
item.description: A 10-month-old French bulldog, who was stolen from a downtown Vancouver tattoo parlour and art gallery Thursday, has been reunited with her owner.

item.title: Canada gets Happy with Pharrell Williams dance videos
item.description: Canadians are getting into the worldwide spirit of happiness, posting their own tributes to the Pharrell Williams hit song Happy on YouTube.

item.title: SkyTrain door opens early during morning commute
item.description: SkyTrain commuters got a bit of a scare when a door slid open while the train was still approaching Edmonds Station in Burnaby, B.C. on Wednesday morning.

item.title: El Nino forecast suggests next winter will be warm
item.description: Good news: Next winter won't be nearly as cold and snowy as the one we just endured, climatologists predict.

item.title: McDonald's foreign worker practices halted in face of investigation
item.description: McDonald's Canada is putting its temporary foreign worker program on hold while a third party conducts an audit on its use of the plan.

item.title: B.C. health worker fired for not getting flu vaccine
item.description: A B.C. care aid was fired for refusing to get vaccinated against influenza or wear a mask this past winter, B.C.'s Health Minister Terry Lake has confirmed.

item.title: Should Chinese-only Crest toothpaste ad concern Richmond residents?
item.description: A Richmond woman has renewed her call for a ban on Chinese-only signage, after ads for Crest toothpaste appeared in several city bus shelters.

item.title: School music programs may be saved by extra funding
item.description: Elementary school music programs in Vancouver may have been saved from budget cuts after the B.C. Ministry of Education announced an additional $585,000 in holdback funds.

item.title: Abused dogs and cat investigated by BC SPCA
item.description: The BC SPCA is investigating three cases of animal cruelty in the southern interior, as the province observes Animal Cruelty Prevention Day.

item.title: Border wait times short this Easter weekend, CBC readers said
item.description: The Canada Border Services Agency launched a new tool in time for the Easter weekend to help travellers minimize their wait time crossing the border into Canada from the U.S. CBC asked readers to tell us where they crossed and how long they waited. Here's what readers tweeted.

item.title: Gas price jump 'doesn't make sense'
item.description: Drivers looking for a good reason for major gasoline price jumps across Canada overnight will be left lacking, as the usual seasonal influences don't add up to those types of increases.

item.title: Bobcat attacks hiker's dogs near Squamish, B.C.
item.description: Several dogs have been attacked by wild bobcats in Squamish's Alice Provincial Lake Park, prompting conservation officers to warn hikers to be extra careful.

item.title: Rail safety improvements announced by Lisa Raitt in wake of Lac-Mégantic
item.description: Transport Minister Lisa Raitt is announcing today new safety rules to prevent tragedies like the one that destroyed part of Lac-Mégantic, Que., last summer. CBCnews.ca is carrying her press conference live.

item.title: Abused dogs and cat investigated by B.C. SPCA
item.description: The B.C. SPCA is investigating three cases of animal cruelty in the southern interior, as the province observes Animal Cruelty Prevention Day.

item.title: Gas price jump defies logic
item.description: Drivers looking for a good reason why gasoline prices made major jumps across Canada overnight will be left lacking, as the usual seasonal influences don't add up to the types of increases they're seeing.

item.title: Bobcat attacks hiker's dogs near Squamish
item.description: Several dogs have been attacked by wild bobcats in Squamish's Alice Provincial Lake Park, and conservation officers are warning hikers to be extra careful.

item.title: Teachers' job action starts today at B.C. schools
item.description: Recess will be cancelled in several school districts across B.C. as the province's 41,000 public school teachers begin job action on Wednesday.

item.title: Vancouver School Board moves to protect music programs
item.description: Elementary school music programs in the Vancouver School District may have been saved from budget cuts after the Ministry of Education announced will give the board an additional $585,000 in hold-back funding.

item.title: Lisa Raitt to enhance rail safety measures in wake of Lac-Mégantic
item.description: Transport Minister Lisa Raitt will announce today new safety rules to prevent tragedies like the one that destroyed part of Lac-Mégantic, Que., last summer. CBCnews.ca will carry her press conference live at 12:45 p.m. ET.

item.title: B.C.’s youngest chief balances major development with tradition
item.description: At 24, Bryce Williams is the youngest chief in B.C. He’s juggling an up-market housing development and the construction of the second-largest mall in Canada with a plan to create a new generation of Tsawwassen artists.

item.title: Kenzie Markey, injured skydiving in Arizona, comes home to B.C.
item.description: Kenzie Markey's landed at the Vancouver airport Tuesday night and with daylight fading was loaded in a stretcher onto a waiting ambulance for transport to Lionsgate Hospital in North Vancouver, B.C.

item.title: Small fire on Grouse Mountain near Capilano Lake
item.description: A plume of smoke has been spotted rising from trees on Grouse Mountain near the west side of Capilano Lake.

item.title: Angila Wilson's killing shocks Clearwater, B.C.
item.description: The community of Clearwater, B.C., is in shock and mourning after Angila Wilson, a nurse and mother of three was found dead around 10 a.m. PT Monday after police were called to check on her well-being.

item.title: Angila Wilson killed in Clearwater, B.C., community in mourning
item.description: The community of Clearwater, B.C., is in shock and mourning after Angila Wilson, a nurse at Dr Helmcken Memorial Hospital was found dead around 10 a.m. PT Monday after police were called to check on her well-being.

item.title: Kenzie Markey, injured skydiving in Arizona, returning home to B.C.
item.description: Kenzie Markey's family has managed to secure an air ambulance to bring her home from Arizona, where her medical bills have climbed to more than $500,000 since her skydiving accident April 6.

item.title: B.C. car dealers may be violating drivers' privacy, claims whistleblower
item.description: A whistleblower in the auto sales industry says car dealers may be violating customers' privacy rights when they scan licences of propective buyers before they take a test drive.

item.title: CFB Esquimalt sailor found dead in Tanzanian hotel
item.description: A Canadian sailor based at CFB Esquimalt in B.C. has died in hospital in Tanzania. The Department of Defence says the sailor was on leave from his duties aboard HMCS Regina, which is currently operating in the Indian Ocean

item.title: Vancouver clinic changes may leave patients without doctors, says report
item.description: An external review commissioned by Vancouver Coastal Health says its plans to change services at a number of health clinics could leave vulnerable patients without doctors.

item.title: No dedicated food inspectors in Vancouver after CFIA cuts, says union
item.description: Metro Vancouver is now the only major metropolitan area in Canada without dedicated food inspectors to investigate cases of food fraud and unsafe retail food displays.

item.title: Long-time Coquitlam family doctor retires
item.description: A vanishing breed of family doctor is retiring after nearly 60 years as a practising physician in Coquitlam. Dr. Dr. Yan So works six to seven days a week, makes house calls and looks after his own patients whether they're in hospital or care homes

item.title: No dedicated food inspectors in Vancouver after CFIA cuts
item.description: Metro Vancouver is now the only major metropolitan area in Canada without dedicated food inspectors to investigate cases of food fraud and unsafe retail food displays.

item.title: Humpback whale losing 'threatened' status amid Northern Gateway concerns
item.description: The Canadian government is downgrading the protection of humpback whales off the coast of B.C. under the Species at Risk Act amid fears that the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline will turn the whales' habitat into a major oil shipping corridor.

item.title: Teck to cut 600 jobs and delay reopening of B.C. coal mine
item.description: Teck Resources says it will reduce its global workforce about five per cent, defer equipment purchases, reduce spending on development projects and delay the restart of its Quintette coal mine in British Columbia until market conditions are more favourable.

item.title: Mother's slaying may have been witnessed by children in Clearwater, B.C.
item.description: Police in Clearwater, B.C., are recommending a man accused of killing his estranged common-law wife be charged with first-degree murder.

item.title: Huge pile of records to land on Truth and Reconciliation Commission's doorstep
item.description: After nearly four years of public hearings and with the clock ticking on a final report into the legacy of physical and sexual abuse at Indian residential schools, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission is about to get a pile of new documents.

item.title: Humpback whale losing 'threatened' status despite Northern Gateway concerns
item.description: The Canadian government is downgrading the protection of humpback whales off the coast of B.C. under the Species at Risk Act amid fears that the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline will turn the whales' habitat into a major oil shipping corridor.

item.title: Some B.C. schools cancel recess as teachers' job action starts
item.description: Tomorrow, teachers across British Columbia will stop carrying out tasks and duties considered "non-essential" by the B.C. Labour Relations Board, including supervising students at recess.

item.title: Endangered mussel surfs Japanese tsunami debris to B.C.
item.description: A non-indigenous mussel that likely hitchhiked its way across the Pacific ocean has been discovered on suspected tsunami debris from Japan's 2011 earthquake.

item.title: Urban beach proposed for New Westminster waterfront
item.description: Metro Vancouver's newest beach could be in New Westminster if council approves the continued redevelopment of its waterfront that begain with the opening of Westminster Pier Park in 2012.

item.title: Earth Day 2014: Electric cars at a 'tipping point'
item.description: Cars powered by electricity such as the highly touted and fun-to-drive Tesla are challenging the auto industry status quo, but hurdles remain before they will displace gas vehicles on the road.

item.title: Earth Day: Is sewage sludge safe for farm fields?
item.description: The use of treated sewage sludge on agricultural land is a well-established if sometimes controversial practice. Researchers are now delving more deeply into biosolids, looking to find any potential contaminants.

item.title: Clearwater, B.C. RCMP surround home: unconfirmed reports woman dead
item.description: RCMP in Clearwater, B.C. surrounded a home Monday night and brought in Emergency Response Team members and a police helicopter after reports a man had barricaded himself inside a home.

item.title: Kelowna's Liz Borrett,75, wins her age group in Boston Marathon
item.description: Kelowna marathoner Liz Borrett was the top finisher in the 75- to 79-year-old age group for females in Monday's Boston Marathon.

item.title: B.C. pot producer, Health Canada recall 'purple kush' marijuana
item.description: Health Canada and a producer of medical marijuana in B.C. have issued a recall notice for a batch of cannabis, citing "issues with the company's production practices."

item.title: Clearwater, B.C. RCMP surround home
item.description: RCMP in Clearwater, B.C. have surrounded a home and brought in members of the Emergency Response Team.

item.title: Fire guts Coquitlam, B.C., home after family escapes
item.description: Dramatic video shot early Monday morning and uploaded to YouTube shows flames devouring a house and garage and spreading to an SUV parked in the driveway.

item.title: Transgender students included in Vancouver school policy review
item.description: A local trans-rights advocate is applauding the efforts of the Vancouver School Board to update its school conduct guidelines to better support transgender students.

item.title: Air Canada suspends workers after luggage-drop video surfaces
item.description: Air Canada says it has suspended some employees after a video of baggage handlers dropping luggage from a tall staircase into a bin below surfaced online last week, and their "employment will be terminated pending the outcome" of an internal investigation.

item.title: Missing B.C. truck driver found dead in Calgary
item.description: John Oswell left Langley, B.C. Thursday morning in a B.C.-registered transport truck, en route to Airdrie, Alta. He never arrived.

item.title: Amanda Todd case: Will the accused stand trial in Canada?
item.description: Authorities in British Columbia are anxious to bring a Netherlands resident to a Canadian courtroom on charges relating to the online sexual extortion​ of a Port Coquitlam teenager, but legal experts say it's unclear when or even if they might get the chance.

item.title: Economic Action Plan ad questions dropped from survey
item.description: The Finance Department has ordered its pollsters to stop asking Canadians potentially embarrassing questions about Economic Action Plan advertising.

item.title: Lower loonie no big deal, 54% of business owners say
item.description: The fluctuating loonie may actually have little impact on most Canadian businesses, suggests a new survey by the Bank of Montreal.

item.title: What's open and closed across Canada on Easter Monday
item.description: It's a holiday and it isn’t across Canada today. While government employees have the day off — meaning no postal service, for example — most retail businesses are open on Easter Monday.

item.title: B.C. marathoner returns to stand strong with Boston
item.description: A B.C. woman who narrowly missed the deadly explosions at last year's Boston Marathon says she's running the race today in solidarity with the city.

item.title: B.C. truck driver and rig go missing en route to Alberta
item.description: Police say a Langley, B.C., man driving a transport truck to Airdrie, Alta., was last heard from Thursday morning.

item.title: 20th 4/20 marked with mass light-up at Vancouver Art Gallery plaza
item.description: Thousands of people are amassing this afternoon at the Vancouver Art Gallery for 4/20, marking the last official gathering of the annual made-in-Vancouver rally at that site.

item.title: 4/20 turns 20 with final Vancouver Art Gallery plaza light-up
item.description: Thousands of people are amassing this afternoon at the Vancouver Art Gallery for 4/20, marking the last official gathering of the annual made-in-Vancouver rally at that site.

item.title: B.C. environment minister warned about LNG greenhouse gas emissions
item.description: British Columbia Environment Ministry staff have warned their minister that the province's dreamed-of liquefied natural gas industry poses some big challenges with greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: B.C. environment minister warned about LNG emissions
item.description: British Columbia Environment Ministry staff have warned their minister that the province's dreamed-of liquefied natural gas industry poses some big challenges with greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: B.C. refugee mental health help funding drastically cut
item.description: The federal government cut almost of all of its funding for agencies that had been offering mental health services to thousands of traumatized refugees.

item.title: Air Canada flight from Vancouver carried child with measles
item.description: Health officials in Edmonton are issuing warnings after a passenger who arrived in the city on a flight from Vancouver was later diagnosed with measles, but similar warnings have not been issued in Vancouver.

item.title: Mounties on medical, stress leave fear new dismissal process
item.description: The RCMP is making it simpler to release officers with serious medical problems, prompting fears that many ill members will be sent packing without due process or the means to fight their dismissal.
